byline.original: By AMY CHOZICK and YAMICHE ALCINDOR

abstract: Enthusiasm over prospect of Hillary Rodham Clinton becoming first female president is often split along generational lines, with older voters who experienced more sexist time responding more to idea than younger generation; strong likelihood of Clinton being nominee has prompted many women to consider how much gender should factor in their vote.
lead_paragraph: In a renewed effort to attract younger women to her campaign, Hillary Clinton is now more intent on trying to forge common cause on specific issues, and less on merely shattering the glass ceiling.

headline.main: Moms and Daughters Debate Gender Factor in Hillary Clinton’s Bid
headline.print_headline: Historic Aspect of Clinton’s Bid Divides Women by Generation

snippet: In a renewed effort to attract younger women to her campaign, Hillary Clinton is now more intent on trying to forge common cause on specific issues, and less on merely shattering the glass ceiling.
